'''''Podostroma cornu-damae''''' (Japanese: カエンタケ), also known as '''Poison Fire Coral''',<ref name=Guardian2019/> is a species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Hypocreaceae]]. The [[ascocarp|fruit bodies]] of the fungus are highly [[mushroom poisoning|toxic]], and have been responsible for several fatalities in Japan. The fungus contains several [[trichothecene]] [[mycotoxin]]s.

==Taxonomy==
{{update-section|date=June 2019}}
The species was [[species description|originally described]] as ''Hypocrea cornu-damae'' by [[Narcisse Théophile Patouillard]] in 1895,<ref name=Patouillard1895/> and later transferred to the genus ''Podocrea'' in 1905 by [[Pier Andrea Saccardo]].<ref name=Saccardo1905/> In 1994 Japanese mycologists [[Tsuguo Hongo]] and Masana Izawa placed the species in the genus ''[[Podostroma]]''.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Podostroma cornu-damae"/>

==Range==
The fungus was thought to be native to Korea and Japan, but recent discoveries have been made in Java, Papua and northern Australia.<ref name=Guardian2019/><ref name=ABC2019/>

==Description==
The [[conidiophore]]s (specialized fungal [[hypha]]e that produce [[conidia]]) are up to 400 [[micrometre|μm]] high and about 2–4 μm wide in the main axial hyphae. The [[phialide]]s are arranged in tufts with narrow angles at the top, similar to the branching hyphae found in ''[[Trichoderma]]'' species. The conidia are roughly spherical with a truncate base in each spore, pale green in color, and measure 2.5–3.5 μm in diameter. Their surfaces are almost smooth, but sometimes appearing very faintly roughened with light microscopy.<ref name=Doi1973/>

==Toxicity==
Several poisonings have been reported in Japan resulting from consumption of the fungus. In 1999, one of a group of five people from [[Niigata prefecture]] died two days after consuming about {{convert|1|g|oz}} of fruit body that had been soaked in [[sake]]. In 2000, an individual from [[Gunma prefecture]] died after eating the fried mushroom. Symptoms associated with consumption in these cases included  stomach pains, changes in perception, decrease in the number of [[leukocyte]]s and [[thrombocyte]]s, peeling skin on the face, hair loss, and shrinking of the [[cerebellum]], resulting in [[speech impediment]] and problems with voluntary movement.<ref name=Saikawa2001/> In another instance, an [[autopsy]] revealed [[multiple organ failure]], including acute [[kidney failure]], liver [[necrosis]] and [[disseminated intravascular coagulation]].<ref name=Koichi2003/> In one case of poisoning, the patient suffered from [[hemophagocytosis]], in addition to severe [[leukocytopenia]] and [[thrombocytopenia]], seven days after ingesting the fungus. [[Plasmapheresis]] and administration of [[granulocyte colony-stimulating factor]] were used to treat the blood disorders. The authors suggested that these treatments, in addition to the large volume of administered [[intravenous]] fluid—{{convert|9|liters}} over a 12-hour period—were responsible for his successful recovery.<ref name=Suzuki2002/>

The poisoning symptoms are similar to those observed previously with animals that had consumed [[trichothecene]] [[mycotoxin]]s. Japanese researchers detected the presence of the [[macrocyclic]] trichothecenes [[satratoxin H]], satratoxin H 12′,13′-diacetate, satratoxin H 12′-acetate, and satratoxin H 13′-acetate. When grown in [[liquid culture]] the fungus additionally produces [[roridin E]], [[verrucarin J]], and satratoxin H. With the exception of verrucarin J, a 500-microgram dose of all of these compounds, when injected into the abdomen of mice, will result in their death the following day.<ref name=Saikawa2001/> It has been claimed that touching the fungus can cause skin irritation, but this is controversial.{{Citation needed|date=October 2019}}
